text:
- We are heading into the
Glacier Walk here in Grindelwald.
I hear it's supposed to be a lot of fun.
(bright music)
- It's huge!
(bright music continues)
- [Narrator] Glacier Canyon
is one of the coolest attractions
in Grindelwald, Switzerland.

The Swiss Alps might be the
top draw in Grindelwald,
but Glacier Canyon is a unique experience
that is affordable and easy to see
in just a couple of hours.

We're going to take you on
a trip through the canyon

and show you why it's one
of the top attractions
in the Jungfrau region.
- Let's go, into the gorge!
(gentle music)

- [Narrator] Take a walk
along an 870-meter-long series

of bridges, tunnels,
walkways, and rocky outcrops,
as the Lutschine River roars
through the 250-million-year-old canyon.
Weaving through the 300-meter-high cliffs

makes for an amazing
afternoon in Grindelwald.

The canyon is located
just a five-minute drive
from downtown Grindelwald

and you can easily catch bus
122 from the town center.
- It's a really beautiful canyon.
The water is rushing through the gorge.

It's just, to see the power
that this Mother Nature has

to cut through this canyon over
the centuries is incredible.
You can go on a little trampoline
that goes right out over the gorge.
It's a whole lot of fun.
Here I go!

A highlight of the
Grindelwald Glacier Gorge
is the 170-square-meter spiderweb
spanning across the rushing water.

You get to stand right over
the river, and it's so cool.
(gentle music)
It's a fun adventure for the whole family
and kids will especially love it,
but it will bring out the kid in you too.
I'm in the middle of the gorge!
Whoo!

And if you're really, really
in the mood for adventure
you're gonna wanna do the canyon swing.

- [Narrator] If you've always
wanted to do a bungee jump,
take a leap off the 90-meter-high platform

to plunge into the canyon
at 120 kilometers per hour
in a wild free fall

before swinging back and forth
over the Lutschine River.
(lively music)
- The walk begins at the Visitor Center
where you go through a museum

to see the geology and history
of the glacier and canyon.
You then walk through a long tunnel
to get to the extraordinary gorge,

where the sound of water
rushing instantly hits you.

(water roaring)
So thunderous!
It's amazing!
The power of this canyon is incredible.
- [Narrator] This 870-meter-long path,
which is about half a mile, is quite easy

and is good for the whole family,
including your family pet.
- I would not want to fall down here.
Whoo!
There's people with dogs and kids.
I'd never do it.
I'd never do it.
I don't even trust myself.
(lively music)
This is amazing.

Just look at this walkway
that we're walking on.
It's a narrow gorge.
It's truly an adventure.
When I saw the pictures,

I thought it was maybe
for kids or something,
but no, it is a wild gorge.

- [Narrator] There are
tunnels to go through,
lookouts, rocky overhangs,

and sitting areas to take in
the 300-meter-high cliffs.

But the real thrill is to
be able to walk so close
to this incredible, rushing water.
- Wow, this was surprising.
I knew I was coming to a canyon

but I really didn't know how
massive and fast this water is.
If you come up to Grindelwald,

get into the Glacier
Canyon to see these rapids.

Wouldn't you like to
white water raft this?
Whoa!
(lively music)
Grindelwald Glacier Canyon

has attracted visitors
since the early 1900s,
and today there is a long walkway

secured with metal railings
leading all the way to the end
of the nearly-kilometer-long trail.
You can no longer see the glacier,
but it's still an amazing attraction.

It doesn't take too
long to get to the end,

but do take your time to
really enjoy all of the views.
So I would recommend giving yourself
at least an hour or two.

Make sure to bring an
outer layer to keep warm
as temperatures cool inside the canyon,
regardless of the weather outside.
(lively music)
Into the caverns we go.

They've just carved
everything out along here
and done an amazing job.

You can just hear the power
here, through the entire walk.
Let's go!
There's some fantastic lookouts.
Look out over here, down at the gorge.
Let's see, I think I saw Dave up there.
Yes, Dave is up there.
Hello, Dave!
He can't hear me.
(lively music continues)
We made it to the end!

It only takes about 20
minutes to half an hour.
We kinda rushed our way out here,
so now we can take our time back.
But we did it, ladies and gentlemen!
(water rushing)
Wow!

And that was a trip to
Grindelwald Glacier Canyon.

If you enjoyed our videos,
make sure to subscribe
because we put up new videos each week
and you don't wanna miss a thing.
